title: coronavirus 5 things must happen
story: NewsCoronavirus:  things that must happen before workers canto the officeThe Trade Union Congress has set out its demands for how Britain could get back to work safely when the lockdown is easedShareCommentsByOliver MilnePolitical Correspondent:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsSome workers have worked through the crisis - others willsoon, but experts are worried about their safety " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailUnions have unveiled the tough new standards they are demanding the Government make sure employers follow to make sure people can go back to work safely. The Trade Union Congress has set out measures which it wants employers to follow before it can they get people back to work. It comes as the body released polling which shows that  in workers surveyed, along with those who have recently become unemployed, are worried about ing to the normal place of work, including halfof women. The same number are concerned about not being able to socially distance from colleagues when back at work, and over a quarterare concerned about not being able to socially distance from customers or clients. Over a thirdare concerned about exposing others in their household to greater risk. And early  in workers across the economy are concerned about not having access to appropriate personal protective equipmentat work. So what is it that the TUC want  A risk assessment in every workplace The core of the TUC demands is that every workplace should carry out a specic Covid- risk assessment. And it should set out specic steps, including enforcing social distancing and what extra safety precautions and equipment is necessary for the government to do its jobs. They then want this arrangement about ing to be agreed by the staff trade union and have it signed off by a health and safety expert. PPE provided where necessary They are calling for all necessary personal protective equipmentto be provided and insist that no one should be asked to re-use PPE inappropriately. Where risk assessments show that PPE is necessary, employers must provide this, and no-one, including Public Health England, should require health and social care workers to re-use PPE.  Specic advice for those at most risk The TUC is calling for the Government to provide specic advice and protection for those groups most at risk. This includes workers advised to ‘shield’ and those who are pregnant. If these workers cannot work safely, their livelihoods must be protected, they demand. And they must monitor the effects of these changes on workers from groups with protected characteristics - like black workers and pregnant women. Punish companies who force people to work in unsafe environments Trade unionists are calling on the Health and Safety Executiveto apply sanctions to employers that do not risk assess for Covid- or fail to provide safe working arrangements. Alongside this, they demand that the HSE run a public information campaign to ensure workers know their rights and extra resources to make inspections quicker. Where companies fail to act, the TUC say that the HSE should prosecute them. Reforming support for schemes to keep people in work The governmentaposs furlough support scheme has kept many people in work through this crisis, but the TUC say it must be made more flexible as Britain s to work. This means allowing the scheme to protect short-time working, to enable people toto work gradually. They also say the scheme must protec those who cannot work, including those who are shielding or caring for someone shielding, parents who cannot work while schools are closed, and those who are ordered to self-isolate by the contact-tracing And that the rate of sick pay and universal credit should be raised to the equivalent of a week’s pay at the real living wage, and £ respectively. The five week UC wait time must also be axed.  Why is this necessary  According to TUC General Secretary Frances O’Grady too often decent employers are let down by those who play fast and loose with safety. She said: “We need tough new measures from government to reassure working people that their health and safety is a priority. Too many workers have already been forced to put their health on the line during this pandemic. “We all want everyone to get back to work and start rebuilding Britain. But workers need confidence that they won’t have to put themselves or their families at unnecessary risk. “Government must ensure that every employer performs a comprehensive risk assessment before asking staff toto work. And bosses who don’t take steps to protect workers should be prosecuted. “If workers are asked to work in conditions they think are unsafe, they can refuse. And they should know that their unions will have their back.”

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAfter more than a month of being cooped up, lockdown-weary Brits have been given a ­glimmer of hope over ato something resembling normal le. Boris Johnson, on his first day back at work after his own battle with ­Covid-, announced he will this week unveil the first steps to easing the restrictions aimed at beating the virus.The Mirror understands one option on the table is allowing people to expand their “social bubbles” so they could see some friends and family. But the PM warned the UK was still at “maximum risk” from the disease and now was not the right time to end the lockdown totally – which could lead to a dangerous second peak and ­thousands more fatalities. Downing Street also warned that in some areas there could be a toughening of the restrictions – including a -day quarantine on new arrivals at British ports and airports.It came as Rishi Sunak revealed the lockdown is having dire consequences for businesses, with a quarter of all firms having stopped trading.The Chancellor announced a new “micro loans scheme” to help small companies in trouble. As the death rate on Monday rose by  to ,, Mr Johnson ­promised to give more details “in the coming days” about how to ease the ­restrictions. One possibility is two ­separate households, or couples who don’t live together, may be able to spend time together. But grandparents who live in a dferent town from grandchildren would still have to wait until ­restrictions are eased further to be able to see them. Ministers are expected to discuss plans to keep ­non-essential ­businesses free from coronavirus so they can reopen in the weeks ahead.Mr Johnson acknowledged there were signs the UK was “passing through the peak” of the outbreak and coming to the end of the first phase. Monday was the first time the daily hospital death toll has been below  since last month. But the PM said: “Dficult ­judgments will be made and we cannot spell out now how fast or slow or even when those changes will be made.” And Chief Medical Officer Chris Whitty admitted the Government faced “some very dficult choices” to keep the ­transmission rate low. Downing Street said any changes to the lockdown would involve “refining” it rather than lting it completely. A spokesman said: “There could be easing in some areas. There could also be a toughening in other areas.”  Ministers plan to recommend wearing face masks on public ­transport, at the shops and in some workplaces. Some football matches and other sports fixtures could resume but would be played behind closed doors and televised.  The Treasury is also looking at how small non-essential business such as garden centres could resume trading. Opening of schools is not expected to be addressed publicly before the next review on May , although there is some optimism among officials they could reopen in June. The business loan announced by Mr Sunak will range from a minimum of £, to £, and firms must have been up and running before the start of March to be eligible. Former minister Theresa Villiers urged him “to publish a road map to release from the lockdown so that businesses can start to prepare for a phased modication and a safe exit from the emergency measures”. Global stock markets staged a £billion rally yesterday as other countries began easing restrictions. But the FTSE  index had a £billion rise, despite our own ­lockdown not yet being lted. The Government is ramping up its “test and trace” strategy, with Matt Hancock claiming the UK was “on track” to deliver on his promise of , a day by the end of the week. But they hit just , tests yesterday.

title: how apply new coronavirus bounce
story: NewsHow to apply for new coronavirus bounce back business loans worth £,The government will now provide % guarantees on loans to Britains smallest businesses - a week after dismissing calls to do so. So whats changed and how do you apply  Here are the basicsShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political EditorOliver MilnePolitical Correspondent:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsBusinesses have been hit particularly hard by the lockdown " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailSmall businesses will be eligible for new loans worth up to £, in the coronavirus crisis. The aposBounce Backapos loans will be backed by a % government guarantee, Chancellor Rishi Sunak said. The top Tory said it was the latest move to shield the economy and workers from the coronavirus shutdown. But it comes after the Government faced weeks of criticism for slow progress in getting government-backed credit to companies. And as recently as last week, Mr Sunak opposed % government guarantees - suggesting the % guarantee on an existing loan scheme was enough. Hereaposs how the new loans work and how to apply.What has changed  Under the existing scheme, Coronavirus Business Interruption Loansworth up to £m are offered to small firms with a certain level of turnover. But they are only backed by the government up to %, leading to a flood of complaints that firms were struggling to get the money out of lenders. Chancellor Rishi Sunak made reforms to CBIL, but he still faced calls to raise the guarantee from % to %. Instead, he has decided to launch a brand new scheme with % guarantees, but worth a much smaller £,.  Why did it need a new scheme  Sources suggested the dference was one of scale. CBILS is worth up to £million per firm - meaning % guarantees would have been more expensive for the government. The other issue is speed. Having a smaller cash amount means there can be fewer checks and the money can go out of the door more quickly. How will the new loans work  Businesses will be able to borrow between £, and £,, with the risk underwritten by the government. The aim is to make it much faster for the cash to get to smaller businesses, who have seen delays going through regulation checks from banks.  How much are they worth  According to Rishi Sunak: Businesses will be able to apply for these new bounce back loans for % of their turnover up to a maximum of £,. The government will cover interest and fees for the first year, with firms expected to repay the loans for five years after that. Sources insisted the interest rate - which some lenders were accused of inflating under CBIL - will be very low. When can you apply for them and where  The scheme will launch for applications on Monday  May and firms will be able to access these loans through lenders accredited through the British Business Bank. The loans will be available from am with no forward-looking test of business viability, no complex eligibility criteria, just a simple, quick standard form for businesses to fill in. Firms are expected to get funding within  hours of applying. Does my firm qualy  There is no limit on a firm’s turnover and firms do not need to show proof of turnover. But sources expect only smaller firms will apply because of the limit on funds. How will they help small businesses  The government says it has designed the scheme to be fast, and affordable. Banks have reportedly agreed on low-interest rates with the government, who will cover those payments for the first year. The % backing from the Treasury will also allow the banks to carry out fewer checks, although they will still be subject to fraud investigations, meaning they should be approved quickly.

Boris Johnson pledged this morning that more details on changing lockdown laws would be revealed in the coming days. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailClap on Thursday, sunbathe on Friday. That’s the way it will work, won’t it, as more and more people flout the lockdown  They’ll argue they love the NHS then ignore the numbers, prioritise their own civil liberties and give the health services a bit more work to do. The reality for me – and for millions of the UK’s black, Asian and mixed-race people – is that to break the lockdown is to play Russian roulette with our lives. The Intensive Care National Audit and Research Centre has found a third of people in intensive care with coronavirus are BAME –black, Asian and minority ethnic. That’s more than double the % they represent of the UK population.  NHS England has said their data for the first , deaths from the virus reveals black people are losing their lives at nearly twice the rate of their proportion of the population. Nobody knows why. When you consider that the , people dead do not include those in care homes or in their own homes , the BAME statistics could be even worse.

And just take a look at these amazing people using lockdown to achieve extreme feats. aposEverest in a monthapos challenge Jo Moseley is on day  out of  of her Everest in a month challenge on an aerobic step in her back yard – and is at ,ft. She wants to keep fundraising for her local foodbank after she reaches the ,ft goal and may even climb another mountain. Jo, , of Skipton, North Yorks, says: “Friends of friends came up with the idea. I began posting my efforts online and the response was great. “I get anxious easily and one way it shows up is my legs don’t want to move – so moving my legs is good to focus on breathing.” Jo is no stranger to a challenge – she was the first woman to paddle board coast to coast last year, all while picking up litter. She says: “When my mum died I rowed a million metres on an indoor rowing machine. “I never try to be the fittest, fastest or the strongest, I just do it because it lts my soul.” Kitchen ultra-marathon  Running across his kitchen, Sean Wilson isn’t rushing to boil the kettle. He’s just completed km – just over  miles – in his home. Sean, , says it’s just the boost he’s needed in these dficult times. The personal trainer from Colchester, Essex, says: “I was feeling sorry for myself. I had no work and was feeling a bit useless. “I researched charities and Age UK really resonated with me – as the older generation are probably most hit by what is going on. “Someone had done a marathon in their garden, so I wanted to do something more extreme. We have a small flat, which is . metres long and we worked out km would be , laps.” The former Marine started at am on a Friday and completed it on am on Saturday. But he admits: “I didn’t realise how hard it would be. With all the stopping and turning you can’t really get any speed up. “The pain in my knees, my feet and my back consumed my thoughts from km onwards. I was on the edge of not making it.” But he found motivation in his friends, family and girlfriend, Sophie, , and raised £,. Paddling pool marathon  Teenager Hannah Buzzard turned her love of swimming and the clever use of a ft paddling pool into fundraising for Blood Cancer UK. The -year-old completed a marathon in the water in just a week – raising more than £. Hannah, who lives in Gosport, Hants, with sister, Liberty, eight, and mum Marie, says: “I’m a competitive swimmer and I wanted to do something to make me swim so chose a marathon distance.” Hannah attached a bungee around her waist, which was tied to a fence – so she could swim without moving for  s a day. Hannah says: “I was swimming around  minutes a day. It was very, very cold. My mum works on the support line for Blood Cancer UK – I’m really proud I could help.” Wheelchair ultra-marathon  Brynn Hauxwell is covering , miles – theof the Shetland coastline – in a wheelchair on an exercise roller in his front room. Brynn,  today, has autism, ADHD, asthma and fixed ankle contractures – which means his foot is fixed at a  degree angle. He said: “I can’t put my foot fully flat down on the ground which means I can’t really walk long distances. “But I’m normally quite active in my wheelchair and enjoy archery and mono-skiing. I haven’t been able to do that at the moment, so this challenge has given me something to focus on and has taken my mind off the situation around the world.” Brynn is raising money for Ability Shetland, which provides support to disabled people all over Shetland. He says: “At the moment I’m doing five miles a day – which takes about six hours. “I’ve had great support from my family and a lot of support online. It makes me feel really good.” Tour de Lounge  Nick Spooner, , was diagnosed with Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease when he was . The condition creates a weakness in nerves and muscles – meaning Nick often broke and sprained his ankles. It also meant he could no longer enjoy sport. Over the past couple of years he has had both of his legs operated on to aid his illness. Nick, from Sheffield, said: “Just as I was able to start moving again, the lockdown happened. “So I thought I would take this opportunity to use my indoor bike to raise funds for Hope Not Hate. I decided I wanted to cycle theof the Tour De France but had no idea how long it was.” Undeterred, he drew out a map for his ,-mile trek. He said: “It’s going well so far and I’m really enjoying it. “ Nick has so far cycled  miles and raised nearly £ –and is considering doing a challenge for real after lockdown.

story: NewsNine simple changes you can make to help cut your chance of getting cancerThere are a number of foods that when added to your diet can have health benefits, according to Cancer Research UKShareCommentsByMichele O’ConnorSam Rkaina:,  APR NewsThere are a number of straight forward lestyle changes you can make" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailOne in two people born after  will develop cancer in their letime, says Cancer Research UK. But around  per cent of cancer diagnoses are preventable. Michele O’Connor has the vital statistics to help you cut your chances of developing the disease. Eat four Brazil nuts every day Brazil nuts are high in the mineral selenium, which many of us are ­deficient in. This powerful antioxidant has been associated with a reduced risk of bladder, prostate and skin cancer. In fact, an Australian study showed that those with the highest selenium levels had almost % fewer skin cancer tumours. Count your coffees  Five daily cups is associated with a % decreased risk of bowel cancer – compared to drinking none. Four cups a day may reduce the risk of developing mouth and pharynx cancers by % and two cups can reduce liver cancer risk by a third. Get outside Getting  to  minutes of sun exposure a day can help raise your vitamin D intake. Japanese researchers who examined , men and women aged -, found that higher levels of vitamin D were linked to a % lower risk of liver cancer, while overall cancer risk was % less. Breakfast on yogurtResearchers found that those who ate a daily serving of yogurt lowered their risk of lung cancer by % compared to those who didn’t. And a Hard Medical School study found that men who had two or more servings of yogurt per week lowered their risk of precancerous growths in their colons by %.  Swap white bread and rice for brown A review of  studies by Cancer Research UK found the risk of bowel cancer was reduced by % for every g of total dietary fibre and cereal fibre consumed each day. Furthermore, g of wholegrains daily accounted for a % reduction in risk . Buya dog It’s well proven that owning a dog has numerous health benefits but a recent study published in the journal Cancer Epidemiology showed that people who owned a dog or cat were almost % less likely to develop non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma – a type of cancer that affects the body’s cells. Experts believe that exposure to pets helps build up our immune systems. Eat three portions of fish per week  Those who enjoy fish on a regular basis have a % lower risk of bowel cancer than those who eat less than one portion per week, say experts from the University of Oxford and the ­International Agency for Research on Cancer who examined the dietary habits of , people. Add garlic Chinese scientists who looked at , lung cancer patients and , healthy adults found that participants who ate raw garlic at least twice a week were % less likely to develop lung cancer. And the World Cancer Research Fund states that garlic could protect against colorectal and stomach cancer. Wait  minutes after chopping or crushing before you cook through – this allows the enzyme alliinase to start a reaction that produces protective allyl sulfides.

title: too early reopen schools coronavirus
story: NewsToo early to reopen schools as coronavirus spread among children largely unknownScientists are still trying to work out how the virus affects children and spreads between them as worrying symptoms emerge in some youngsters infected in the UKShareCommentsByTaz Ali:,  APR NewsHealth Secretary Matt Hancock today said it was too early to make a decision on reopening schools " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Experts say there is not enough evidence to reopen schools yet because it is still unclear how coronavirus spreads among children.Schools and colleges have largely been closed under lockdown, except to children of essential workers and vulnerable youngsters. But it is thought they could be among the first places to reopen once restrictions start being eased. However chief medical officer Professor Chris Whitty said that while a great majority of children either do not contract the virus or have mild symptoms, there is still not enough data on how youngsters contribute to the spread of the deadly Covid-. It came as reports emerged today of unusual symptoms in children with coronavirus, that Health Secretary Matt Hancock today  said left him aposvery worried.aposA dozen children have been taken to intensive care with the symptoms which appear similar to toxic shock syndrome.Prof Whitty today explained how the lower the transmission rate of coronavirus - or R value - the greater room for manoeuvre there is for what lockdown measures could be lted. Speaking at the Downing Street briefing today, Prof Whitty said: If you have schools open, it does contribute to increasing the R. If you close schools, the R goes down, it was part of the collection of things that were done in March to try and pull the R from where it was, near three, to where it is now, below one. He added: If you stopped doing it, you would actually lose some of the benefit that we have currently got. But we do not yet have direct data that really help us in assessing the impact, he said. There is more accurate information on how children spread diseases such as flu, Prof Whitty said, but we are still really learning on how they spread Covid-.  He added: Whilst I think it remains the case that the contribution of children at school is probably less than, for example, flu, we do think it certainly contributes. What we are trying to work out is what proportion of the R it contributes and therefore,children went back to school, how much closer to one - and thataposs in a bad way - would we be and could it even tip us above one. He said scientic advisers would present a range of options to ministers about easing lockdown measures and dficult choices would have to be made. Prof Whitty added: There is no perfect solution where we are going to end up being able to do all the things that people want and, at the same time, keep R below one.  So, there are going to have to be some very dficult choices between dferent things, all of which ideally all of us would love to open up, but we canapost do them all. Therefore, there will have to be some dficult choices, and choices around schools clearly will be one of those.

Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailWe have been told by government to expect a “new normal” when measures to ease lockdown are eventually brought in. We know a complete lting will not happen. Rather, a gradual “moving” towards a new status quo. But quite when that will begin to happen, what will move first, and for whom, is yet to be established. Here, we take a look at the possibilities and potential time scales for Britain’s very dferent normality. What will it mean for you  Schoolchildren Kids could be first in the queue for ‘normal’. Experts cite schools reopening as a first phase, which could happen this side of the summer holidays, or be delayed until September. Italy has opted for the latter, while in Denmark kids under  were allowed back earlier this month. Germany has drawn up guidance for reopening some schools from early May, with measures including spacing between desks and staggered break times. Dominic Raab has agreed social distancing measures would need to be in place. The Scottish government has suggested classrooms might be re-designed. Professor Keith Neal, an expert in Epidemiology of Infectious Diseases at the University of Nottingham, explains coronavirus doesn’t appear to affect children under  – so they might be first to .He also explains evidence has not actually revealed kids pose a spreading risk. He said: “Schools ing should be one of the first measures but it will be a staged response, and schools will need to look at their building size. Alternate weeks might be one option.” Over s First it was suggested elderly and high-risk groups should isolate for  weeks. Now reports have hinted they might have to stay at home until a vaccine is found – potentially up to  months. But already there are hints of a rebellion from those in the age category who are fit.  Lord David Blunkett has argued: “Older people must not be subjected to arbitrary incarceration as well as isolation.” And Caroline Abrahams, Charity Director at Age UK, added: “Simply being over a certain age, say , does not seem a good enough reason on its own to force millions to shut themselves away for considerably longer than everyone . “The Government should develop the next stage of its advice on the basis of the best science that exists and older people should make their own decisions about the risks they are prepared to take, bearing in mind their state of health.” However, Professor Neal says even those aged  without underlying conditions are at greater risk. He said: “Regardless of how fit you are, the ageing immune system is the problem. The mortality rate of -year-olds is around %, by the time you get to  it’s approaching %.” Construction Some building firms have started to reopen sites already, and others have planned for May, albeit with social distancing. Guidance from the Construction Leadership Council outlines where workers are required to work within two metres of each other, they should “work side by side, or facing away from each other, rather than face to face”.  When this is not possible, workers should “keep this to  minutes or less where possible”. Professor Neal says outdoor working with social distancing poses a very small risk. Factories Factories are also going back to work, with carmakers including Jaguar Land Rover, Aston Martin and Nissan announcing the gradual , with social distancing. In Germany, in one Volkswagen plant, production will be just -% to begin with, and nudge up. There, extra measures include workers taking their temperature before entering. Shop workers Dominic Raab has suggested social distancing queues and markers could be adopted in non-essential shops. Plastic screens at tills could also be introduced. Garden centres might be some of the first to re-open. Some are already offering click-and-collect services. John Lewis has also revealed a blueprint for potential re-opening, showing phases of– first including only stores with large car parks so staff and customers don’t need to rely on public transport.  A report by retail trade body the British Retail Consortium has stated guidelines including the closure of changing rooms in clothes shops, closure of toilets, restricting the numbers of shoppers according to shop size, and limiting or removing seating and promotional stands to make more room, as well as one-way systems and separate exits and entrances. Professor Neal stresses as this is mainly a respiratory virus, the risk of it transferring via fabric in clothes shops is low. And he added any outdoor business poses a minimal risk, alongside social distancing. Generally, he said shops should re-open soon. “At the moment, shop workers don’t seem to be falling ill in large numbers, because the situation is being managed,” he said. Hairdressers and beauticians These businesses could be last in the queue. “This is an up-close activity, it’s a problem,” says Professor Neal. “Social distancing is virtually impossible. If we can drive the disease to very low levels they could re-open.” Pub and restaurant workers There’s no doubt these are high-risk. A study in China revealed in January, a diner at a restaurant spread coronavirus to nine others, all sitting at their table. The British government is said to be closely observing the five-point plan of the Czech Republic, which states restaurants could serve customers outside by the end of May, and start to serve indoors by June. Sweden kept theirs open – but with no queuing at the bar, and table service only.  Professor Neal feels these venues will open late down the line, but some measures could help. “Distancing between customers is key. If you go with a family member that’s very dferent than going with a group. So you could have small tables, certain distances apart. You might also want to screen more at the bar, or go for table service,” he says. “And being outside is completely dferent. Beer gardens opening first might be a sensible option.” Office workers A packed office is certainly a long way off – and may never be seen again. If people need or want to go back, social distancing will be key, so part of the workforce will have to stay home to make space.  Communal kitchens and water coolers will be out. Professor Neal suggests it’s an unnecessary risk. “Work at homeyou can, why not ” he says. Pregnant women Pregnant woman were placed in a vulnerable group by the Chief Medical Officer in March, meaning they were advised to reduce social contact through social distancing measures. But The Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists and the Royal College of Midwives has reassured women there is no evidence to suggest pregnant women generally are at greater risk from Covid-.

title: you need know coronavirus tests
story: NewsCoronavirus tests explained: Whether you can get one and how it worksPublic Health England’s antigen test was one of the first developed to locate Covid- genes in swab samples - but the UK is still going to fall short of Matt Hancocks , daily targetShareCommentsByMartin BagotHealth and Science editor:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsThe UKs current testing procedure involves motorists driving to testing centres" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Earlier this month Health Secretary Matt Hancock set an ambitious target of , daily coronavirus tests across the UK by the end of April.It appears that the Government will fall well short of this goal - but the capacity and overall testing numbers have increased. And officials have now made tests available to all those classied as key workers during the pandemic. What is the test and who can get it  The test to find outyou have coronavirus is known as the polymerase chain reactiontest. Public Health England’s “antigen test” was one of the first developed to locate Covid- genes in swab samples. It was developed after Chinese scientists in January released details of the new coronavirus’s full genetic code. Since testing of the general public was abandoned on March  the UK has had so little testing capacity that only hospitalised patients were given it. This was then extended to NHS staff - after an outcry due to so many being off work - and then to social care workers. Since Friday all ten million key workers have also been entitled to a test as well as anyone living with them. All jobs which qualy for ‘key worker’ status are listed on the Government’s website. They include police, firefighters, prison guards, refuse collectors, power station workers, council staff as well as workers in transport, education and the production or sale of essential goods. How can people get tested Key workers and their families who want a test can visit www.gov.uk enter their details.They should then receive a text or email the same day inviting them to book an appointment at a drive-through testing site, or notication they will receive a home testing kit. Test results from the drive-through sites should be sent out by text within  hours. Results of home test kits would be sent out within  hours of collection. However a limited number of test slots are available and home testing kits have run out after a few hours each morning. Slots at drive through centres have lasted a little longer each day. Why is all test capacity not being used up  The Government boasted of having test “capacity” well above than the number of tests that were actually being carried out. That was because carers were not getting access to home testing kits while drive-through test centres were often many miles away. The location of testing centres meant patients feeling very ill would have to drive for hours to provide their swab sample.  To use up this extra capacity access to testing has been opened up to all care workers while more testing sites are set up. The Government has said it is aiming to get to  testing sites and as of yesterday said  were up and running. Is the UK test reliable  Public Health Englandwas one of the first organisations outside of China to implement a diagnostic test. Recently a leaked PHE document warned some test results may be unreliable. The document from its National Infection Service advised technicians to be careful before “calling” a result negative to “retest ambiguous samples”.  PHE refuted claims as many as % tests were giving  negative results insisting it was as good as other tests being used where. Infection director Prof Sharon Peacock said: “No diagnostic test is % sensitive. The test is regularly and thoroughly reviewed to make sure it remains reliable and effective.” All tests can be gradually improved as more information comes to light about a new virus. Pharmaceutical firms are also developing tests and PHE plans to switch to a commercial test at some point in future. Why is the number of tests higher than the number of patients tested  Public Health England says that some people require more than one test for clinical reasons. This includes people having dferent samples taken, for instance a throat swab and a nasal swab. Some have an inconclusive first test or medics decide to double-check a negative result from someone who had previously been positive. What is contact tracing  This involves identying and alerting people who may have been exposed so that they can protect themselves and others around them. It could be used for someone has tested positive for coronavirus, or have reported symptoms to the NHS meaning they are likely to have Covid-. Clinicians would then gather information about places they have visited and people they have been in contact with. To help with contact tracing , people are being recruited who will help noty people who has come in to contact with a Covid- case.  An NHS app is currently being developed which could identy people who have been in proximity to a smartphone user who then developed coronavirus symptoms. Using Bluetooth Low Energy signals, the app will log each time it comes into close range of other devices also running the app. The app keeps an anonymous record of all these logs securely on a user’s phone. If someone develops symptoms of Covid-, they can use the app to inform the NHS, which will then trigger an anonymous alert to any other app users the infected person came into contact with by analysing the collected logs. The app will then advise what action to take, including telling people to self-isolatenecessary. A date for the app’s release has not been confirmed but the NHS said it will be “in the coming weeks”. The app isn’t compulsory, but those who don’t download it or don’t have a compatible phone will potentially miss out on knowing quicklythey might be infected. Can you get Covid- more than once  The World Health Organisation caused concern over the weekend when it warned that there is “no evidence” that people who had Covid- will be immune. It then retracted the warning to re-phrase it as it was seen to imply that people do not become immune to future infections. The truth is there is not enough reliable data at the moment to say either way as the new virus has not been around long enough. Howeverit behaves in a similar way to other forms of coronavirus virus then being infected is likely to see the body develop antibodies that see the patient become immune for months or even years. Prof James Naismith, of Oxford University, said: “It seems certain that almost all people who have been infected will have complete immunity against re-infection for at least a short time.  “We know that for many coronaviruses, immunity weakens in many people over a few years, and for this reason some viruses infect and re-infect people. “We do not, and cannot, know for sure how Covid- will behave. “So-called ‘immunity passports’ for previously infected people are political inventions built around complex scientic concepts. “Only a safe and effective vaccine, that I believe will come in the future, will deliver widespread immunity from infection.” What is the antibody test  The antibody test measures the levels of these antibodies in someone which would suggest whether someone has previously had Covid- and is now immune. If the tests are accurate enough, they could potentially identy iniduals who are at least in part protected against the virus.Prime Minister Boris Johnson said a successful test would be a “game changer” as it could identy people able to safely go back to work.The home test versions of the test - similar to a pregnancy test - still have poor accuracy rates so are too unreliable to be offered to the general public. It needs to achieve a high degree of accuracy to prevent carers from ly believing they are immune. A more reliable test, which needs to be sent off and analysed in a lab, is being trialled on a sample of the population.  This should give an idea of what proportion of the UK have had Covid-. However the test is not accurate enough for the results to be relied on by the iniduals taking part. The government has reportedly placed a provisional order for up to  million new antibody test kits. They are being developed by the newly formed Rapid Testing Consortium at Oxford University. Why is testing important  Widespread testing is key to lting some lockdown measures and ing some degree of normality to Britain before a vaccine is developed. Health Secretary Matt Hancock said that once testing capacity is high enough it could be used as part of a nationwide track and trace operation. This would only be enacted when infection rates are very low and would rely on a mass public participation.  Some social measures could be lted while mass testing monitored infection rates. If infection rates started to surge then lockdown measures could be reintroduced. How would a vaccine work  The great hope for ato normal le is a vaccine. The first human trial of one in Europe began at Oxford University last week with two volunteers. One was injected with a potential vaccine and the other with a control product. Scientists developing a second potential vaccine at imperial College London will start recruiting volunteers for clinical trials to begin in June. The Oxford vaccine will try to stimulate the immune system using a common cold virus taken from chimps The researchers at Imperial are using droplets of liquid to carry the genetic material they need to get into the bloodstream.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Doctors in the US have updated their official symptoms of coronavirus after doctors reported seeing them time and again.Initially the Centre for Disease Controllisted just three symptoms for Covid- which were: shortness of breath, a cough and a fever. But as doctors have learned more about the deadly bug, which has claimed the lives of more than , people in the UK, they have updated their list of symptoms. The CDC in America now reports the symptoms which could appear between two to  days of exposure to the virus as:Chills Repeated shaking with chills Muscle pain Headache Sore throat New loss of taste or smell In an  Iranian study, % of Covid- patients who reported a loss of smell said it had a sudden onset. In many of the cases, anosmia, as it’s called, appeared before other symptoms.Vallery Lomas, a -year-old champion baker, told the Washington Post: “It scared the hell out of me. “I could smell nothing for probably five days.” Professor Claire Hopkins, president of the British Rhinological Society and a leading ear, nose and throat consultant surgeon, is leading the charge to get loss of sense of smell recognised by the World Health Organization and Public Health England as a coronavirus symptom.  Prof. Hopkins said: One in six patients will lose their sense of smell as an isolated symptom, really without getting any other associated symptoms. One in four will get it along with other symptoms, but right at the beginning of infection. It is a good early marker of infection. She added: When you look at all the dferent symptoms, loss of sense of smell is actually one of the best predictors of Covid- infection. Much better than fever, and more prevalent and a stronger predictor than cough. In France, researchers are preparing to launch a human trial to test their hypothesis that nicotine can help the body combat the Covid- infection.  The trial will involve groups of healthcare workers and patients wearing nicotine patches and other groups wearing placebo patches. Then they will be tested to seethere is a dference in how their bodies respond to the virus. The trial is a follow-up to a French study, published this month, of public health data which appeared to show that people who smoke are % less likely to catch Covid- than non-smokers of the same age and sex. The most common symptoms of the coronavirus are: a dry, persistent cougha feverIf you experience these symptoms, you should immediately self-isolate yourself for seven days. It is not necessary to call NHS  unless your symptoms get more severe. Some patients have reported fatigue, headaches, shortness of breath and aches and pains. Sneezing is not a symptom of the coronavirus.

story: NewsGirl swaps family portraits for crayon drawings and no one notices for  daysKristen Vogler was bored in coronavirus lockdown and wanted to see how long it would take for her parents to realise she was swapping the family portraits with crayon drawingsShareCommentsByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  APR NewsKristen got her inspiration online after seeing someone replace their family portraits with pictures of Nicholas Cage " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA woman bored in lockdown pulled a hilarious prank on her family and it ended up lasting a total of  days. Kristen Vogler, , started replacing family photos at their home in Massachusetts, with crayon drawings to see how long it would take for her parents Mike and Paula, both , to notice. Kristen got her inspiration from social media after she saw someone had replaced all of their family pictures with portraits of Nicholas Cage - and thought it was hilarious. But since she didnapost have pictures of Nicholas lying about - and she did happen to have loads of crayons - she did the next best thing and recreated each portrait in crayon. Kristen started creating the drawings when her family were out on their daily walks and was shocked when she managed to keep it going for  days. She said: It was so funny because they walk through the door next to the photos probably five of six times per day. It was hard to keep it up without giving it away.Kristen kept people updated with her quest on Twitter posting pictures everyday with a new crayon portrait, and the hashtag #quarantineactivites.On the first day she wrote: After FaceTiming with my grandparentsfor an hour and having neither parent notice.  I decided to add the second piece while they went for a walk. This is my best work yet. On day four she had a small scare when her mum told her she was going to create a Twitter account but she ended up getting locked out of it - result.  And on day , hours before she was finally caught out, she wrote: I thought the jig was up today when my dad came running downstairs while I hung my latest crayon replica but I managed to get it done in time.  But later that same day she said: We were in the house and it was raining like crazy, we were just looking out of the window and my mum walked past the photos, did a double take and just said aposwhat is that apos They had a good laugh about it but of course my dad said heaposd always known in the back of his mind. Kristen posted the video online which has since gone viral, receiving more than , likes. She continued: The video got a lot more attention than I thought it would. My mum and dad keep asking for updates on how many views and shares itaposs had. My dad challenged my mum to a bet thatit reached one million views in a week he wouldnapost have to eat any more broccoli for the rest of the year. It has given us a lot of entertainment. Itaposs a fun thing for everyone to laugh at and itaposs fun seeing the reactions and the comments.

The surgeon was said to have made a mistake because his hands were shaking so much. It has been reported that Kim had thanked workers on the project in the city of Wonsan, where a train believed to be his has been spotted in satellite images amid unveried reports that he is either dead, in a vegetative state or alive and well. Kimaposs whereabouts and the status of his health remain a mystery as he has not been seen in state media reports since April , the day before he reportedly had the operation. It is just the latest in a long line of bizarre stories surrounding the controversial leader - from feeding his uncle to dogs to executing a general in a James Bond-inspired killing. Kim Jong-unaposs weight has ballooned in recent years to a massive -stone, said to be fuelled by his obsession with Swiss cheese. And his waistline isnapost the only thing thataposs suffered. The leader is said to be suffering from the painful condition, gout, because of his love of the fatty food. As far back as , he was spotted limping at the anniversary of his grandfatheraposs death. North Korea expert Michael Madden thinks the tyrantaposs weight gain - his father died of a heart attack - and genetics point towards gout. He said: Based on his gait, it appears he has gout - something due to diet and genetic predisposition that has affected other members of the Kim family. Kimaposs love of cheese is said to stem from when he was a student in Switzerland. He was special shipments delivered and has also sent envoys to France to try to enrol North Korean cooks on cheese-making courses. In , Kim reportedly had to briefly retreat from public le after eating too much Emmental cheese, after a large shipment of it arrived from Switzerland. He might not look the type but Kim Jong-un appears to be a massive fan of music and even formed his own girlband. Moranbong is one of the most famous bands in North Korea and were founded by the leader himself. The band, known for their military unorm-style costumes, extravagant shows and synthesizer-backed anthems, were among the country’s delegation to the Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang, South Korea, in . A year later, the girls were all put on a regimented diet to standardise their waistlines, according to North Korea watchers Sino-NK. And not surprisingly, most of the girl band’s songs appear to be about the North Korean leader himself. “How can he be so kind,” the lyrics to one ballad go. “His smile is so warm and sweet. In  North Korean authorities issued an order requiring men to keep their hair no longer than cm, while woman were required to keep their hair bobbed. Young men have been told to model their hairstyle on the supreme leader’s own eccentric style, where the sides and back of the head are almost clean shaven and only the top is left. Young men are supposed to wear their hair in a bobbed cut like Kim’s we Ri Sol-ju. Only performers are now allowed to grow their hair, according to reports. A Pyongyang source said that the order was being enforced in the country’s universities, where “university student monitors are walking around with scissors and cutting off the hair of offenders.” Kim himself, however, is believed to be scared of barbers, so he cuts his own hair. And the supreme leader has a very famous best friend - basketball superstar and former Chicago Bulls player, Dennis Rodman. Kim has been a basketball fan since he was a teenager and would spend hours drawing his favourite player, Michael Jordan. His dreams to meet one of his heroes finally came true in  when Rodman visited North Korea. At the time Rodman said: My mission is to break the ice between hostile countries. Why it’s been left to me to smooth things over, I don’t know. Dennis Rodman, of all people. Keeping us safe is really not my job it’s the black guy’s [Obama’s] job. But I’ll tell you this: If I don’t finish in the top three for the next Nobel Peace Prize, something’s seriously wrong. Vice Minister of the North Korean Army, Kim Chol, was purged back in  for drinking and carousing during a period of mourning for his former leader. But this was no ordinary execution by firing squad. Chol was rumoured to have been exploded by mortar bombardment. Vice Marshall Ri Yong-ho was another of Kimaposs inner circle to lose his le in . Despite leading Kim Jong-ilaposs funeral procession at the side of his son, he was said to have been executed the following July. Ri Ryong-has was one of Kimaposs uncleaposs aides and the leader was said to have been very drunk when he ordered both his and jang Su-gil in  by firing squad. Choe Yong-gon was North Koreaaposs Vice Premier when he suddenly disappeared from public le in , and is believed to have been executed. Even being the brother of the despotic leader doesnapost keep the ruling family safe. Kim Jong-unaposs half-brother, Kim Jong-nam, was reportedly assassinated after being found dead in an airport. He had been seen as the heir apparent to his father Kim Jong-il, however he fell out of favour a few years before the dictatoraposs death. Instead, his brother Kim Jong-un took control of the country and was allegedly behind the death of his half-brother at a Malaysian airport in . One of the women accused of murdering Kim Jong-nam at Kuala Lumpuraposs international airport was released from prison earlier this year.

title: dundee deefiant ross county
story: “It felt like we had won the league” – Dundee finishing sixth in the second tier wouldn’t usually spark frenzied celebration but nine years ago today the class of   cemented themselves in club folklore.‘Deefiant’ status was confirmed with a - win at Ross County on April ,  # a single goal from -year-old Leighton McIntosh causing “an explosion” in the stands, according to the Dundonian.Months after administration had seen the Dark Blues given a huge -point penalty by the league, Barry Smith’s beleaguered side beat the odds by avoiding the drop to the Second Division.The campaign had begun with swingeing cuts across the club’s staff, leaving a skeleton squad to battle against what seemed like the rest of the world.Current Dens youth coach Gary Irvine had not long been signed by Gordon Chisholm from St Johnstone before the club was plunged into a financial crisis.He told the Tele: “The -point penalty came in and it felt like they were kicking us when we were already down.“From our point of view, it felt like they were trying to put the club under with that – I think it is the biggest points penalty ever handed out. We felt very hard done by.“The boys who were kept on were feeling really fortunate because they were still getting paid.“I don’t knowit was the plan from the bosses to pick a team that could compete but we ended up with a really good team with some good youngsters left behind.“There was real quality and we said ‘let’s have a go’.”Despite being left with a threadbare squad, former club skipper Smith had some real talent to choose from that season with a good mix of youth and experience.The older heads included former Scotland internationals Rab Douglas and Neil McCann as well as experienced campaigners like Rhys Weston and Matt Lockwood while the younger ones included future Scotland star Leigh Grfiths, Dens hero Gary Harkins and defender Craig Forsyth among others.Called up from the youth team was also striker McIntosh, who hit a purple patch of goals at a critical point in the season – an equaliser against Stirling Albion followed by a double at Morton # before the Dark Blues went north to Dingwall.The match that clinched their unlikely survival turned out to be his final one of the season, however.McIntosh said: “When the match started I actually felt my hamstring go because of the demand of all the games before Ross County.“I think I actually tore the muscle and it was only about  minutes in. I knew the gaffer could tell something was wrong but, being young and naïve, I played through it.“It got worse and worse but it got to the point where I forgot all about it and then got the goal after half-time.“I was always motivated to chase down long balls and this time the goalkeeper took his time.“I nicked it from him and I don’t think I even considered anything about what to do next, it was natural. It was a great feeling despite the pain in my hamstring.“It was a really nice day up there I remember and the supporters were there in their numbers, it was an electric atmosphere.“I scored right in front of them and it was like an explosion.“There won’t be any other games with that kind of circumstance I don’t think, it was unique.“I remember the celebrations on the pitch – it was like we’d won the league. Everyone was ecstatic and it was just pure relief.“I don’t think I realised at the time how signicant it was. My focus was only on playing well and trying to make it as a first-team player.“It was a massive game looking back.“I still get Dundee fans coming up to me in the street to say they were there.”On the game itself, McIntosh’s then team-mate Irvine admits it was all a bit of a blur looking back.He added: “I remember Leighton’s goal, he was one of the really good young boys who did just as much as the older experienced lads.“It was the only goal of the game and, at the end, it felt like we had won the league. The feeling and the celebrations afterwards for what we achieved were amazing.“I’ve always said nothing comes close to that season. I’ve won three league titles and won Challenge Cups where you get a medal at the end for your hard work – there was no medal at the end of that one but I still class saving Dundee and keeping them in the league as my best achievement.”Irvine went on to spend six years at Dens Park as a player before ing as a coach where he took the U  side before the coronavirus shutdown.McIntosh, meanwhile, has had spells at Montrose, Peterhead, Icelandic side UMF Selfoss, Arbroath and Airdrie before signing for National League side Wrexham.Following the departure of manager Bryan Hughes, the now--year-old joined Lee Clark’s Blyth Spartans on loan until the pandemic hit.Despite his contract in Wales running down this summer, McIntosh is sanguine about his future.He added: “I took the opportunity to go down south and I’ve enjoyed it. It’s very competitive and the full-time setup was a big plus for me, too.“Everything is up in the air right now and I’ll have to wait and see what pre-season brings, whenever it starts.“I am out of contract this summer but I understand the furlough scheme will cover out-of-contract players for a time so I’m not overly concerned.“It is what it is, everyone is in the same boat.”🔵 In these troubled times, when many people are struggling to get out for their paper, we are pledging to help readers by providing a FREE digital edition of the Eveningfor three months. title: dundee united dave bowman monchengladbach jim mclean
story: Dundee United legend Dave Bowman believes their  win over Borussia Monchengladbach trumps Barcelona and Roma as the club’s greatest-ever result.United saw off the Germans - at the Bokelberg Stadion  years ago today to reach the Uefa Cup Final thanks to second-leg goals from Iain Ferguson and Ian Redford.They had beaten Barca - on aggregate in the previous round, while a -  European Cup semi-final first-leg win over the Italians at Tannadice is in the history books despite United not making the final.However, Tangerines hero Bowman remembers the Monchengladbach result with most fondness.“Monchengladbach were a really big team at the time, both them and Barca were, but I think the big thing was Monchengladbach got us into a final,” the former United midfielder said.“Nobody remembers who loses the semi-final. I wasn’t there at the time but nobody really remembers the Roma European Cup semi-final too fondly but they’ll always recall Barcelona and Monchengladbach.“Getting into the final was a massive thing for the city and the club but at the time, as players, nothing was really a surprise for us.“We were expecting to get there so when we did it was great to do, don’t get me wrong, but it wasn’t as much of a surprise to us as it was outsiders.“At that time there was the European Cup, Cup Winners’ Cup and the other teams went into the Uefa Cup.“When you think about that in recent terms, Liverpool didn’t win the league last season but they won the Champions League.“That was the sort of level we were up against. It was a huge achievement.”Bowman recalls United going into the second leg riled up after witnessing some premature celebrations from the Monchengladbach players after a stalemate in Dundee.The -year-old also remembers a rare occasion where legendary boss Jim McLean inidually congratulated his players after the final whistle.Bowman, who made  appearances in tangerine, added: “Under wee Jim we were always taught, unless it was the second leg and you had to win at home, as long as you didn’t lose a goal it was OK.“That was the biggest thing, from our point of view, we didn’t get beat and we weren’t up against it.“I remember they were celebrating after the first leg and that probably gave us a bit of impetus to go on and beat them.“They were high-fiving each other because they got a - and thought the tie was over so that annoyed us a bit.“It made such a dference for us going there at - and Iain getting the goal just before half time.“They had to really come at us because they needed to score two.“Going into half time it was a massive advantage but I can’t really remember us being under that much pressure.“We knew they had to score two which was a tough ask against our defence. It was quite comfortable.“They didn’t have a lot of chances. Big Thommohad some great games and made some big saves that season but I can’t really remember him having to be brilliant.“Heggiesaid to me after it, ‘You should take this all in,’ and I was probably very naïve and just thought this happens every year, we’ll do it again next year.“I probably didn’t appreciate it as much as what I probably should have. It’s only when you look back.“It’s probably one of the only times I can recall Jim coming round and shaking everybody’s hand in the dressing-room after the game.“He really pushed us to our limits and got the best out of everybody. If he could see you had something he would get it out of you, how he did it was irrelevant.“He was very guarded towards us but he went round and congratulated everyone inidually.”United went on to lose the final - over two legs against IFK Gothenburg, with a - Scottish Cup Final defeat to St Mirren sandwiched in between.Bowman believes had they beaten the Buddies they might’ve gone on to secure the Uefa Cup, too.He continued: “It shows how much the SFA helped us at the time! We played the Scottish Cup Final on the Saturday and the second leg of the Uefa Cup Final on the Wednesday.“It was for the good of Scottish football we were trying to win it as well. I thinkwe’d beaten St Mirren, we would’ve had a lot better chance.“There’s no way of saying we’d have definitely beat Gothenburg because they were a decent team but the St Mirren loss was the first down we’d had that season.“Everything was on the up all the time, even with the amount of games we’d played that year.“It was the first time the press had questioned our fitness because we’d played that many games.“You’re never tired when you’re winning but as soon as you get beat that can quickly change.“Personally, all the finals don’t mean anythingyou don’t win. You want to have success by winning and savouring that.”🔵 In these troubled times, when many people are struggling to get out for their paper, we are pledging to help readers by providing a FREE digital edition of the Eveningfor three months. title: former dundee united director calls for spfl to avoid moral bankruptcy and choose 14 team top flight
story: Former Dundee United director David Southern has called on Scottish football to avoid “moral bankruptcy” by embracing a new league setup and avoiding forced relegation.Following last week’s protracted SPFL vote on ending the   season in the lower leagues, Partick Thistle and Stranraer have been left facing demotion from the Championship and League One respectively.The same fate hangs over Hearts should the top flight vote to follow suit and Southern, a former director at Tynecastle, has backed the potential --- model for the SPFL to avoid “gross injustice”.“Can we repair the damage that’s been caused by an unjustly cause to clubs such as Partick Thistle, Stranraer and potentially Heart of Midlothian Football Club ” he told Sky Sports.“What we have to do as Scottish football and the SPFL is avoid moral bankruptcy becausethose clubs are ejected from their leagues there has been a gross injustice.“I do believe that they --- is a highly-acceptable model – it preserves those clubs who would have been unfairly demoted from their leagues, Heart of Midlothian, Partick and Stranraer.“It also allows clubs who were in second place in the Championship, League One and League Two to be promoted up to the next level.“It creates a fantastic top-flight model in terms of Rangers-Celtic matches, the Edinburgh derbies are preserved for broadcasters and you also introduce Inverness and the Highland derbies once again.“No team is damaged,anything other teams will receive a benefit and you also bring in a Highland League champion and Lowland League champion.”Southern left his role as chief operating officer at United last summer after five years at Tannadice.lthr  gtltstronggt🔵 In these troubled times, when many people are struggling to get out for their paper, we are pledging to help readers by providing a FREE digital edition of the Eveningfor three months. title: coronavirus professor hugh pennington details how uk could end social distancing this year
story: Social distancing could be #abandoned# by the end of this yeardecision-makers stopped waiting for a vaccine, an expert claimed.Professor Hugh Pennington, emeritus professor of bacteriology at Aberdeen University, said he was #reasonably optimistic# that the coronavirus outbreak could be #eradicated# in Britain by Christmas by focusing efforts on a huge increase in testing and tracing.If we have an eradication strategy that is successful by the end of the year, then all these things could be abandoned. Even social distancing could go.#Professor Hugh PenningtonThe UK Government is aiming to carry out , tests a day by the end of this month, but Prof Pennington believes the target should be nearer one million.The expert urged ministers to pursue such a strategy rather than pinning their hopes on getting a vaccine, as he warned: #We might never get a good vaccine#.Prof Pennington said schools, shops and restaurants could be the first to reopen, but he predicted pubs may have to remain shut for a longer period, as would restrictions on people coming into the country.#If we have an eradication strategy that is successful by the end of the year, then all these things could be abandoned. Even social distancing could go,# Prof Pennington said.#As long as we still had a really good testing programme to make sure the virus wasn#t still creeping about, and then we would obviously need to have restrictions on people coming into the country from countries where the virus is still busy.#Prof Pennington, who led a  government inquiry into an E. coli outbreak in Scotland, is due to give evidence to Holyrood#s health committee on the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on Tuesday.Professor Neil Ferguson, of Imperial College London, who has been a key adviser to the UK Government on its response to the disease outbreak, has warned that signicant social distancing measures would need to remain in place until a vaccine is created, which is not expected until next year.First Minister Nicola Sturgeon has also said that #some form of social distancing is going to be required perhaps up to the point where a vaccine is available”.But Prof Pennington said government policy should not be based on such hopes.#I think it would be unwise to put all the weight on saying #we#re not going to be able to do this until we get a vaccine#,# he said.#Because, on the one hand, we might never get a good vaccine, because the virus itself might not be knocked back by a vaccine as well as we would like, and the vaccine themselves, there#s a theoretical possibility that some types of vaccine might make the illness worse. We#ve seen that in the past.#I think saying, #we can#t relax this until we#ve got a vaccine# would be a mistake, because that might mean predicating a policy on something that isn#t going to happen.#A vaccine would be nice, it would be greatit worked and it would solve a problem next year, but not this year.#I think the aim has to be to get the virus sorted out this year. The end of the year would be my optimistic target.#I think the aim has to be to get the virus sorted out this year. The end of the year would be my optimistic target.#Professor Hugh PenningtonThe microbiologist, who was chair of bacteriology at Aberdeen University from  until his retirement with emeritus status in , said the #signs are good# that Britain could repeat the examples of China and New Zealand, where there are now few cases.#I think what we should be aiming for is not control of the virus, in the sense of flattening the curve or preventing a second peak, we should be aiming at eradication of the virus,# he said.#I would set Christmas as my target well, just before Christmas, so that people could enjoy it.#I would set it at a target because we#ve got enough time, I think,we are strict about social distancing.#We don#t need to worry as much about some of the lockdown things # we might be able to let the schoolkids back, for example, and shops are beginning to open.#I think the last people who would be benefiting from this would be pubs, because clearly the whole essence of a pub is everybody being close together.#I don#t see why restaurants couldn#t be able reopen,they move the tables apart and all that kind of stuff.#The future of sporting events has been a hot topic in recent weeks, and Prof Pennington believes a major investigation should be held into whether the Cheltenham Festival and Liverpool FC#s match against Atletico Madrid on March  contributed to the spread of the virus.#We should be looking to do that quite quickly because that would give us the evidence on which we could base the release of the lockdown,# he said.

title: argyll sport decimated amid coronavirus response
story: Rachel CarruthersUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsThe coronavirus response has forced the cancellation of sporting events up and down the region.Just when the situation will settle down enough to allow sport to re-start is anyone#s guess at this stage, but early casualties have included shinty, football, athletics and a planned youth football trip to Europe.The committee of Mid Argyll Athletic Club took the dficult decision to postpone the Argyll final of Sports Hall Athletics which was due to take place at Atlantis Leisure in Oban this Sunday, March .With more than  young boys and girls qualying for the final from the four local area competitions and the possibility of another -plus family member spectators filling the games hall the organisers felt it was sensible to postpone the event.A statement from the organisers said: #After consultation with the management staff at Atlantis Leisure it was decided it was best to follow the guidance that is currently being issued by the Scottish Government and others to attempt to restrict the spread of the coronavirus.#We will revisit a date for holding the competition once the coronavirus situation is clear andnecessary this may be have to be after the summer school holidays. The boys and girls who qualied from the local area competitions in Lochgilphead, Oban, Tobermory and Campbeltown will be advised of the new Argyll final date and times through their local club or school.#We apologise for any inconvenience and disappointment this postponement may cause to the young athletes and their families.#The annual Crinan Puffer # an .-mile race between Crinan and Ardrishaig # has also been postponed.A fundraiser for Mid Argyll Community Pool organised with the help of Mid Argyll Athletic Club, the run was due to be held on Sunday March .Announcing the postponement, Kirsty Young of Mid Argyll Community Pool said: #In light of current government guidelines to avoid non-essential contact and unnecessary travel we feel that this is the right decision to make.#I will be contacting all stakeholders involved with the organisation and running of the event in the coming days to try and come up with a date to re-schedule the event.#Months of work to raise money for a trip to Holland in April for young Mid Argyll footballers has come to nothing, thanks to coronavirus.Lochgilphead Red Star  players, coaches, parents and supporters were left disappointed when the Amsterdam tournament was cancelled.A committee spokesperson said: #The team are devastated not to be going after nine months of fundraising for the event. We are lucky enough to be getting a full refund from the organisers and at present are awaiting to seethe same will happen regarding the flights.#We would like to take this opportunity to thank everyone from the public to businesses who have supported us throughout our fundraising, from attending coffee mornings, donating at bag packs and online donations and our hypnotist night. Your generosity has been overwhelming .#We plan to let the kids of the team decide which charities they would like to donate the funds to once we receive the refund.#After just one week of the  season, shinty#s governing body, the Camanachd Association, made the decision on Friday March  to postpone all matches until further notice.The association also recommended that this should include all training, festivals and other events.In a statement, the Camanachd Association said: #In light of the government restrictions on public gatherings and the resulting pressure on emergency services and healthcare provision, the Camanachd Association has postponed all fixtures under our auspices whilst a further assessment can be made and to reduce any additional pressure our activities may have otherwise had on emergency services.#The wellbeing of the people in our communities is primary in this decision and we hope that this decision removes any expectations or pressures on participating during a time that we can be focused on doing all we can to suppress the spread of the virus.#The recommendation is that shinty clubs should hold any meetings using remote technology such as Skype.The association statement concluded: #We will endeavour to provide due notice to clubs ahead of any future shinty matches so as there is time to restart training.#The Scottish Football Association also decided to suspend all matches in the interests of public health for the and health and safety of players, match officials and staff across the game.Ian Maxwell, SFA chief executive, said: #This is of paramount importance as the country enters the #delay# phase of the coronavirus pandemic.#The decision to suspend or continue training is at each club’s discretion at this time, however clubs must ensure to follow the current medical guidance issued by the government and the health authorities when making this decision.Scottish Rugby decided that with effect from Sunday  March at pm there would be a short period without domestic competition or training up to March .This includes rugby in all domestic league and cup fixtures, training, festivals and other rugby events as well as the FOSROC Super tournament, which come under Scottish Rugby#s jurisdiction.The Scottish Rugby age grade programmehas been cancelled with immediate effect for the remainder of the season.A Scottish Rugby Spokesperson said: #We have taken on board all expert medical advice before now and we are taking a precautionary approach to give time to assess what the impact of coronavirus will be on Scottish society in the coming weeks before deciding on next steps.#
